passages.text: EUROPE | European Midcaps

We highlighted Aalberts, Arcadis, MCD and InPost as our top picks for 2H25E, and downgraded Alfen and Fugro to Underperform. DEME's profitability reached new highs, while tender activity remains strong. IMCD's acquisition of Tillmans in Italy confirms its M&A strategy is on track. We preview InPost and D'leteren results due next week. Last but not least, please sign up for the Benelux mid- cap tour visiting 9 companies in two days on Sept 30th and Oct 1st.

Exploring opportunities in European Mid- Caps. Whilst tariffs have held back a broader SMID revival, we already witnessed signs of a trend reversal, following the longest underperformance on record. The anticipation of the German stimulus and a potential ceasefire provides a positive set- up for Europe and re- rating potential for growth- related sectors and cyclical names. In this note, we highlight 15 top picks and change 6 ratings. In the Benelux region, we highlighted Aalberts, Arcadis, IMCD and InPost as our top picks for 2H25E, and downgraded Alfen and Fugro to UNPF.

DEME (DEME BB, Buy) Profitability reaching new highs; tender activity remains strong. 1H25 revenues increased \(10\%\) to €2,117.1m, \(4\%\) ahead of cons. €2,042.8m, driven by growth of \(27\%\) in Offshore Energy, partly offset by lower revenues of \(4\%\) in Dredging & Infra, and \(19\%\) in Environmental. EBITDA surged \(35\%\) to €464.3m, \(29\%\) ahead of cons. €360.3m, implying a 394bps higher margin at \(21.9\%\) , driven by efficient project planning and strong execution in Offshore Energy. Excl. non- recurring income from a settlement fee for a US project in January 2025, and a loss on the construction of the Princess Elisabeth Island, we estimate underlying profitability was 250bps higher at \(20.5\%\) , vs. cons. \(17.5\%\) . Tender activity remains strong, particularly in Dredging & Infra, expected to mitigate \(27\%\) weaker order intake. For FY25E, DEME confirms guidance for turnover to be at least in line with FY24, based on order book, pipeline, and vessel capacity, but now expects EBITDA margin to slightly exceed \(20\%\) (vs. at least stable at \(18.6\%\) previously). We have increased EBITDA estimates by \(10\% - 16\%\) , but lowered our DCF- based PT to €175 for the Havfram acquisition for €900m, with still a limited order book of €530m.

IMCD (IMCD NA, Buy). Acquisition of Tillmans in Italy confirms M&A strategy is on track. IMCD has signed an agreement to acquire \(100\%\) of the shares in Tillmans S.p.A., a well- established distributor of specialty chemicals in Italy, with revenues of €143m in FY24. This marks IMCD's largest acquisition in terms of revenues since the acquisition of Signet in India in 2020, and increases acquired revenues to €338m ytd, adding \(7\%\) to group revenues, amidst recent investor concerns IMCD's M&A strategy was slowing. Tillmans acts as a key partner for global suppliers, with a broad base of customers, focusing on the coatings, construction, food & nutrition, and water treatment markets. Tillmans operates a logistics centre in Milan, and an in- house R&D laboratory, offering advanced testing, custom formulations, and technical support. The acquisition provides a strong strategic fit for IMCD, increasing scale and market presence in Italy, where IMCD realised revenues of €220m in FY23.

InPost (INPST NA, Buy) Preview 1H25 Results. 1H25 results on Sept 2nd are expected to reflect slowing adjusted EBITDA growth from \(24\%\) in 1Q25 to \(12\%\) for 2Q25E, with the recent expansion in the UK temporarily weighing on earnings momentum, as well as a softer e- commerce market in Poland. InPost shares are down \(20\%\) ytd on the back renewed concerns over increasing competition from Allegro in Poland, and trading at \(42\%\) discount to its historical valuation, despite successful international diversification.

Jefferies Benelux Mid-Cap Tour on Sept 30th & Oct 1st. Please join us for the Jefferies Benelux Mid-Cap Tour on September 30th & October 1st in the Netherlands and Belgium. We will visit the management teams of c.10 leading Dutch and Belgian Mid-Caps over two days, with confirmed meetings with Aalberts, Arcadis, Azelis, IMCD, DEME, Fugro, Fastned, Signify, and TKH Group.
Exhibit 5 - Benelux Mid-Cap Tour

Monday September 29th – Arrival Hilton Hotel, Schiphol AirportTuesday September 30th08.00 - 09.30ArcadisBreakfast with Willem Baars (CFO)Amsterdam10.00 - 11.30FastnedMeeting with Victor van Dijk (CFO)Amsterdam11.30 - 13.00TKH GroupMeeting with Alexander van der Lof (CEO)Amsterdam13.30 - 15.00SignifyMeeting with Zeljko Kosanovic (CFO)Amsterdam16.00 - 17.30AalbertsMeeting with Frans den Houter (CFO)Utrecht19.00 - 21.00Dinner Hotel New YorkHost David KerstensRotterdamOvernight stay in Nhow Hotel RotterdamWednesday October 1st08.00 - 09.15IMCDBreakfast with Marcus Jordan (CEO)Rotterdam10.00 - 11.30FugroMeeting with Barbara Geelen (CFO)Leidschendam13.00 - 14.30DEMELuc Vandenbulcke (CEO)Antwerpen area15.30 - 17.00AzelisAnna Bertona (CEO) &amp; Thijs Bakker (CFO)Antwerpen area18.00 -Trains / flights home

D'leteren (DIE BB, Hold) Preview 1H25 results. 1H25 results on Sept 2nd are expected to reflect an \(18\%\) decrease in adjusted pre- tax profit group share to €475.1m, based on the company compiled consensus, mainly driven by higher finance costs, as adjusted operating profit group share is expected to be relatively stable at €696.5m, driven by higher results of \(10\%\) for Belron, and \(5\%\) for PHE, stable results for TVH Parts, offset by \(28\%\) lower results for D'leteren Automotive. Note that relatively sluggish 1Q25 trading was impacted by 1- 2 fewer trading days, which will likely reverse in the remainder of the year (although 2Q25E will likely be held back by the timing of Easter), while a stronger US dollar supported sales in 1Q25, which will likely reverse in the remainder of the year.

- Belron sales increased \(6.4\%\) in 1Q25, with organic growth of \(4.0\%\) , including \(3.3\%\) in North America, \(4.4\%\) in the Eurozone, and \(5.9\%\) in ROW, due to favourable price/mix, ADAS and VAPS contribution, held back by two less trading days.- D'leteren Automotive sales decreased \(16.6\%\) in 1Q25, due to \(29.2\%\) lower deliveries, resulting in a 149bps lower market share.- PHE sales were \(4.6\%\) higher, driven by organic growth of \(3.5\%\) , driven by market share gains.- TVH Parts sales increased \(2.3\%\) , with organic growth of \(0.5\%\) , reflecting a healthy performance in EMEA, partly offset by softer demand in Americas.- Moleskine sales increased \(3.3\%\) , with organic growth of \(1.6\%\) , driven by Americas and APAC, offset by decline in EMEA.

Based on the 1Q25 trading update, D'leteren Group confirmed guidance for a slight increase in underlying pre- tax profit, before additional interest charges of €180m, €54m in FY24, after last year's shareholder consolidation through an extraordinary dividend of €3.9bn, and in year- end FY24 exchange rates, and excluding any potential impact from tariffs. We estimate adjusted PBT group share after additional interest charges will be \(13\%\) lower y/y, reflecting the higher interest costs, following last year's family shareholder consolidation, and a weaker US dollar. Our €196 PT is based on a SOTP- analysis (Ex. 6).
Exhibit 6 - D'leteren Group SOTP-analysis Prices as of August 29th

Alfen (Downgrade to Underperform, PT €8.0). FY26E guidance cut triggers further downgrades. We downgrade Alfen from Hold to Underperform, with a lowered €8.0 PT (vs. €12.0 previously), after the recent FY26E guidance downgrade, reflecting increasing competition in EV Charging in the home segment, permitting delays and labour shortages holding back grid upgrades, and lower battery prices, as well as increased mid- term uncertainty in all segments. 1H25 revenues decreased 14% to €211.5m, driven by 27% lower revenues in Energy Storage Systems, after 40% lower battery prices, and 23% lower revenues in EV Charging, reflecting intensified competition in the home segment. 1H25 adjusted EBITDA decreased only 4% to €13.0m, as cost measures are yielding results, resulting in a 70bps higher EBITDA margin at 6.2%, after 10% lower personnel costs, and 18% lower other exp. For FY25E, Alfen expects c. 7% lower revenues in the range of €430m- €480m, resulting in an EBITDA margin of 5%- 8%, supported by cost savings of €13.0m from last year's 15% headcount reduction. We have made mid- teens cuts to our adjusted EBITDA estimates, reflecting weakening gross margins in 2H25E, due to increasing competition in EV Charging, increasing component costs for smart grids, and a normalisation of gross margins in Energy Storage, resulting in an EBITDA margin of 5.5% for FY25E, near the low- end of the FY25E guidance range of 5%- 8%. Alfen now sees a more limited 0%- 5% revenue recovery for FY26E, vs. 5%- 10% previously, leading to a relatively more stable EBITDA margin of 5%- 8%, vs. high- single digit previously, and drops guidance for a return to a low- double digit EBITDA margin in the medium- term. Alfen shares are down 10% ytd, vs. EuroStoxx +10%, and trading at 10.8x FY25E EV/EBITDA, implying a 60% discount to their historical valuation.

Fugro (Downgrade to UNPF, PT €10.0). Targeted profitability recovery relatively optimistic. We downgrade Fugro from Hold to Underperform, with a lowered €10.0 PT (vs. €12.5 previously), as the targeted profitability recovery for 2H25E looks relatively optimistic, when comparing with mid- cycle margins, while top- line growth expectations have more than halved, from c. 18% early FY24 to c. 8% CAGR for FY24- FY28E today, mainly due to a slowdown in offshore wind, from 30% to 14%, leading to an increased reliance on cost savings. As a result, we still see downside risk to FY25E consensus estimates of up to 25%. Fugro expects 2H25E revenues will be c. 20% higher than 1H25, implying an 8% decrease y/y, supported by postponed orders, and increased customer confidence, underlined by recent large project wins, resulting in FY25E revenues of close to €2.0bn, down 13% y/y. As a result, Fugro expects a FY25E EBIT margin in the range of 8%- 11% (lowered from 11%- 15% on August 1st), implying a 2H25E EBIT margin of 13%- 18%, vs. the record level of 14.4% in 2H24. The margin target is expected to be supported by targeted cost savings of €80m- €100m, adding c. 4% points to margins, with half of savings related to a headcount reduction of c. 750 FTEs (7% of the workforce). We have cut FY25E EBIT by 25% to €132.1m, assuming a 10.4% mid- cycle EBIT margin for 2H25E, below the record- high level of 14.4% in 2H24, as cost savings and profitability from now projects will likely be back- end loaded. Beyond FY25E, we are projecting high- single digit annual revenue growth to €2.7bn by FY29E, and a 200bps higher EBIT margin at 11.0% by FY29E, vs. the 11%- 15% target range for FY27E. Fugro shares are down 27% ytd, vs. EuroStoxx up 10%, and trading at 9.5x FY26E EV/EBIT, implying a 25% premium to peers. Our lowered €10.0 DCF- based PT values Fugro at 8.0x FY26E EV/EBIT.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company. NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations. Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
